title-group.article-title: A new dwarf gecko of the genus Pseudogonatodes (Squamata: Sphaerodactylidae) from the eastern slope of the Andean Cordillera de MÃ©rida in northern South America

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
A new dwarf gecko of the genus
Pseudogonatodes
( Squamata : Sphaerodactylidae ) from the eastern slope of the Andean Cordillera de MÃ©rida in northern South America
FERNANDO J. M. ROJAS-RUNJAIC 1,2,5, *, CLAUDIA KOCH 3,6 , SANTIAGO CASTROVIEJO-FISHER 4,7 & ANA L. C. PRUDENTE 1,8

1
LaboratÃ³rio de Herpetologia, CoordenaÃ§Ã£o de Zoologia, Museu Paraense EmÃ­lio Goeldi, BelÃ©m, ParÃ¡, Brazil

2
Museo de Historia Natural La Salle, FundaciÃ³n La Salle de Ciencias Naturales, Caracas, Distrito Capital , Venezuela

3
Leibniz Institute for the Analysis of Biodiversity Change, Museum Koenig, Bonn, Germany

4
Departamento de ZoologÃ­a, Universidad de Sevilla, Sevilla, Spain
*Corresponding author: ï¿½ rojas_runjaic@yahoo.com

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Pseudogonatodes
is a poorly known genus of small bodied, diurnal, ground-dwelling geckos widely distributed in northern South America. No additional species have been described in over two decades. Herein we describe a new species from the eastern slope of the Cordillera de MÃ©rida in the Venezuelan Andes. The new species is readily diagnosable morphologically from the other seven recognized species of
Pseudogonatodes
by having a single postnasal scaleâa putative autapomorphy. Furthermore, it is characterized by a unique combination of phenotypic characters that includes granular dorsal scales, three large postrostrals, five to six loreals, mental U-shaped, four to six postmentals, 26â29 ventrals between anterior levels of fore- and hind limbs, third lamella under fourth toe not distinctly enlarged, and subcaudal pattern 1â1â. In addition to characterizing the external morphology, we present a description of the skull, based on 3D digital models reconstructed from high resolution computed microtomography scans. The discovery of this new species highlights the still underestimated diversity of this group of Neotropical dwarf geckos and underscores the need for further studies on its systematics and taxonomy.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words: Gekkota , lizard , Neotropics ,
new species
, osteology , reptile ,
Venezuela

sec.title: Resumen
sec.p:
Pseudogonatodes
es un gÃ©nero de geckos de tamaÃ±o corporal pequeÃ±o, diurnos y terrestres, ampliamente distribuidos en el norte de SudamÃ©rica. Ninguna especie nueva habÃ­a sido descubierta en mÃ¡s de dos dÃ©cadas. En este estudio describimos una nueva especie de la vertiente oriental de la Cordillera de MÃ©rida en los Andes de Venezuela . La nueva especie es fÃ¡cilmente diagnosticada de las otras siete especies de
Pseudogonatodes
reconocidas, por presentar una sola escama postnasalâun carÃ¡cter aparentemente autapomÃ³rfico. Adicionalmente, se caracteriza por una combinaciÃ³n Ãºnica de caracteres fenotÃ­picos que incluye escamas dorsales granulares, tres grandes postrostrales, cinco a seis loreales, mentoniana en forma de U, cuatro a seis postmentonianas, 26â29 ventrales entre los niveles anteriores de los miembros anteriores y posteriores, tercera lamela subdigital del cuarto dedo de la pata no agrandada y patrÃ³n subcaudal 1â1â. AdemÃ¡s de la caracterizaciÃ³n morfolÃ³gica externa, presentamos una descripciÃ³n del crÃ¡neo basada en modelos virtuales 3D reconstruidos a partir de microtomografÃ­as computarizadas de alta resoluciÃ³n. El descubrimiento de esta nueva especie deja en evidencia la subestimaciÃ³n de la diversidad de este grupo de geckos enanos neotropicales y resalta la necesidad de estudios adicionales sobre su sistemÃ¡tica y taxonomÃ­a.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Within
Pseudogonatodes
, three phenetic groups have been defined, based on subdigital and dorsal scale characteristics (
). The first group is defined by having an expanded third lamella on the fourth toe, low fourth toe lamellae count, and granular dorsal scales; this is composed of two species:
P. guianensis Parker, 1935
and
P. lunulatus ( Roux, 1927 )
. The second group only differs from the first one by having large flat and imbricate dorsal scales and is only represented by
P. barbouri
. The third group is characterized by the absence of an expanded third lamella on the fourth toe, a high fourth toe lamellae count, and by having granular dorsal scales; this last group includes
P. furvus Ruthven, 1915
,
P. gasconi Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed, 2000
,
P. manessi Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed, 2000
, and
P. peruvianus Huey & Dixon, 1970
.

Despite the wide distribution of
Pseudogonatodes
in northern South America and its occurrence in four different bioregions, only the seven species listed above are currently recognized.An eighth species (
P. amazonicus Vanzolini, 1967
) from western Amazonia, is currently considered as a junior synonym of
P. guianensis
(
;
) but it awaits a modern taxonomic revision. In addition,
reported and discussed a putative new species from Cundinamarca department in Colombia , but did not formally describe it. Molecular evidence on the occurrence of deeply divergent lineages within
Pseudogonatodes guianensis
published by
as well as some studies in progress (Rojas-Runjaic, pers. obs.) preliminarily indicate that the low number of
Pseudogonatodes species
currently known is likely a consequence of our lack of knowledge about the systematics and diversity of the genus and not of a truly depauperate species richness within this group of geckos.

Two herpetological surveys to the eastern slope of the Venezuelan Andes in 2015 and 2016, resulted in the collection of a small series of specimens of
Pseudogonatodes
. The study of their external morphology revealed that these Andean specimens belong to a new species objectively diagnosable by morphology from all other species currently recognized. In this study we morphologically describe and name the new species of
Pseudogonatodes
and provide an osteological description of its skull from 3D digital models.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
Fieldwork .
A total of seven specimens were collected during two fieldtrips carried out on February 14â15, 2015 and October 17â20, 2016 , in a montane semideciduous forest area of the eastern versant of Cordillera de MÃ©rida , Barinas state , Venezuela ( Fig. 1 ). At this location, diurnal and nocturnal visual surveys were performed for amphibians and reptiles, and collection sites were georeferenced using a GPS receiver Garmin 60CSX with datum WGS 84. The specimens were captured manually and transported in plastic bags to an improvised laboratory in the field, where they were photographed in life. After being photographed, the specimens were euthanized with an overdose of 2% lidocaine administrated by intraperitoneal injection, fixed in a 10% formalin solution, and preserved in 70% ethanol. Prior to fixation, a sample of muscle and/or liver tissue was dissected from some specimens. These samples were preserved in 99% ethanol for future molecular analyses.

Osteology. Detailed description and illustrations on the skull morphology of the genus
Pseudogonatodes
are already available (
) based on the congener
P. barbouri
. Therefore, to avoid redundancy, we do not give a complete skull description of the new species in the results section, but instead concentrate on highlighting the differences from the skull of
P. barbouri
as well as previously uncommented aspects. We further present a comparative synopsis of the skull of our new species with that of
P. barbouri
and
P. furvus
(the type species of the genus). Information on the cranial morphology of
P. furvus
was taken from
and from our own examination of the micro-CT images of MCZ R-29700, downloaded from the MorphoSource.org platform. High resolution computed microtomography scans from the specimens MHNLS 21643 (adult female, holotype ), MHNLS 22711 (adult female, paratype ), and MHNLS 22712 (adult male, paratype ) were conducted using a Bruker SkyScan 1173 X-ray microCT, at the Instituto do PetrÃ³leo e dos Recursos Naturais (IPR) of the PontifÃ­cia Universidade CatÃ³lica do Rio Grande do Sul , Brazil . Specimens were scanned in three or four parts, depending on their size. Scans were performed at a voltage of 43 kV and current of 114 Î¼A, without the use of a filter; rotation steps of 0.25Â° were recorded over a 180Â° rotation and each acquisition was composed of 2,880 (for specimens scanned in three parts) or 3,840 projections (for specimens scanned in four parts), with 550 ms exposure time, three frames averaged per projection, and 8.15 ( MHNLS 21643) or 8.5 Î¼m ( MHNLS 22711, 22712) voxel size. Reconstructions were obtained with NRecon 1.7.1.6 (Bruker microCTÂ®) and visualized with CTvox 3.2.0 (Bruker microCTÂ®). The scan of MHNLS 21643 was rendered in three dimensions and segmented to separate bones with the aid of Amira visualization software (FEI, Thermo Fisher Scientific). As these micro-CT scans do not render cartilage, non-mineralized skeletal structures were omitted from our osteological description. Osteological terminology follows
,
, and
.

mixed-citation.named-content: A new dwarf gecko of the genus Pseudogonatodes (Squamata: Sphaerodactylidae) from the eastern slope of the Andean Cordillera de MÃ©rida in northern South America

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Paratypes :
Six specimens : an adult female ( MHNLS 22711 , field number DQ 83 ), an adult male ( MHNLS 22710 , field number DQ 82 ), and a juvenile ( MHNLS 22709 , field number DQ 81 ), from Sendero El Oso , Posada San RamÃ³n , â
6 km
N from Altamira de CÃ¡ceres , BolÃ­var municipality, Barinas state , Venezuela (8.878750Â°, - 70.497580Â°;
elevation 1,319 m asl
), collected on
October 17, 2016
, by Daniel Quihua , JosÃ© Vieira & Dennys Mora ;
an adult male ( MHNLS 22712 , field number DQ 84) and a juvenile ( MHNLS 22713 , field number DQ 85), from the type locality, collected on
October 20, 2016
, by Daniel Quihua , JosÃ© Vieira & Dennys Mora ; and a juvenile ( MHNLS 21644 , without field number) with the same data as the holotype
.

Definition.
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
is morphologically defined by the following combination of character states: (1) SVL : 27.5â30.2 mm in adult males, 31.3â33.6 mm in adult females; (2) posterodorsal margin of rostral W-shaped, with a median cleft; (3) three postrostrals; (4) median postrostral similar in size to lateral ones; (5) a single large postnasal scale; (6) five to six loreal scales; (7) 19â22 scales in a transverse row between the sutures of the 1 st and 2 nd supralabials on each side; (8) four to six supralabials; (9) four to five supraciliaries, the second being the largest; (10) four to five infralabials; (11) posterior margin of mental U-shaped, without posterior clefts; (12) four to six postmentals; (13) dorsal and lateral scales granular, juxtaposed; (14) 85â91 scales around midbody; (15) 20â22 ventrals in a transverse row at midbody; (16) 40â43 ventral scales along a midventral row, between throat and anterior border of cloaca; (17) 33â36 ventral scales along a midventral row, from anterior level of arms to anterior border of cloaca; (18) 26â29 ventral scales along a midventral row, between anterior levels of fore- and hind limbs; (19) 7â9 lamellae under fourth finger; (20) 8â10 lamellae under fourth toe; (21) third lamella under fourth toe not distinctly enlarged; (22) subcaudal pattern 1â1â.

Diagnosis. The new species differs from the other seven
Pseudogonatodes species
by the presence of a single large postnasal scale ( vs . two or three postnasal scales; see Table 1 ). In addition, it differs from
P. barbouri
by having juxtaposed granular dorsal scales ( vs . flat and imbricate), by lacking an expanded third lamella under fourth toe (TIV) ( vs . expanded), and by its larger body size, which reaches 33.6 mm SVL in adult females ( vs . up to 25.6 mm SVL;
Koch et al . 2018
). It is differentiated from
P. lunulatus
by lacking an expanded third lamella under TIV ( vs . expanded), by having heterogeneous scales on the sole of the foot ( vs . homogeneous), a large median postrostral, similar in size to the lateral ones ( vs . median postrostral smaller than lateral ones), 5â6 loreal scales in a straight line between postnasal and orbit ( vs . up to nine), 4â6 postmentals ( vs . 3â4), 8â10 infradigital lamellae under TIV ( vs . 6â7), and larger body size ( vs . up to 29 mm SVL;
Esqueda et al . 2016
). The new species further differs from
P. guianensis
by lacking an expanded third infradigital lamella under TIV ( vs . expanded), by having 33â36 ventral scales between anterior level of forelimb and cloaca ( vs . 36â47 VMR-b), 8â10 lamellae under TIV ( vs . 5â7), a medial row of slightly expanded subcaudal scales arranged in a 1â1â pattern ( vs . in some cases slightly expanded but without a pattern), and a larger body size in adult females ( vs . up to 30 mm ; Avila-Pires 1995 ).
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
is distinguished from
P. gasconi
by having a medial cleft on the posterior margin of the rostral ( vs . without cleft on posterior margin of rostral), granular dorsal scales ( vs . conical to flat conical dorsals), 26â29 ventral scales between anterior levels of fore- and hind limbs ( vs . 37 VMR-c), 5â6 loreal scales in a straight line between postnasal and orbit ( vs . 7 loreals), a medial row of slightly expanded subcaudal scales arranged in a 1â1â pattern ( vs . subcaudals unexpanded and unpatterned), and a larger body size, which ranges between 31.3â33.6 mm SVL in adult females ( vs . 24 mm SVL in the only known specimen, which is an adult female; Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed 2000 ). It is differentiated from
P. manessi
by having 5â6 loreal scales ( vs . 7â8), posterior margin of mental U-shaped, without posterior clefts ( vs . W-shaped, with or without two posterior clefts), 4â6 postmentals ( vs . 6â9), 26â29 ventral scales between anterior levels of forelimbs and hind limbs ( vs . 31â35 VMR-c), and 33â36 ventral scales until border of cloaca ( vs . 37â40 VMR-b), and a smaller body size ( vs . up to 38 mm SVL; Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed 2000 ). It is distinguished from
P. peruvianus
by having a large median postrostral, similar in size to the lateral ones ( vs . median postrostral about one-third the size of laterals), 85â91 scales around midbody ( vs . 79 SAM), 33â36 ventral scales between anterior level of forelimbs and border of cloaca ( vs . 42 VMR-b). Finally,
P. quihuai
differs from
P. furvus
by having 5â6 loreal scales ( vs . 7â10), posterior edge of mental without clefts ( vs . two median clefts), 4â6 postmentals ( vs . 2â4), 27â29 ventral scales between anterior levels of forelimbs and hind limbs ( vs . 34â39 VMR-c), and 33â36 ventral scales until border of cloaca ( vs . 44â67 VMR-b), 7â9 lamellae under 4 th finger ( vs . 11â13), 8â10 under TIV ( vs . 11â15), and a smaller body size, which does not exceed 33.6 mm ( vs . up to 45 mm SVL;
Montes-Correa et al . 2021
).

Color in life and preservative. In life, dorsal and lateral surfaces of head, dorsum, flanks, and limbs dark brown, with some scattered whitish dots, mainly on flanks; background color of dorsal and lateral surfaces of tail also dark brown, but darker than head and trunk. Dorsal surface of head with a lighter, poorly defined occipital band posteriorly bordered by a thin blackish brown transverse line; supralabials and infralabials mottled blackish brown, with pale vertical stripes on lateral borders of such scales; a pale diagonal postrictal band, finely bordered with blackish brown, extending posteroventrally from angle of jaws to throat, where it continues backwards flanking the throat. A pair of thin, ill-defined, pale dorsolateral stripes extending backwards from postocular corners to distal third of tail, where they become inconspicuous; both dorsolateral stripes finely bordered with blackish brown from posterior third of dorsum to base of tail; from base of tail and to its distal third, pale dorsolateral stripes become broader and slightly sinuous. Chin and throat dirty white, laterally delimited by a blackish line. Chest, belly, ventral surfaces of thighs and tail brown, slightly lighter than flanks and dorsum; all the enlarged scales on these ventral regions are pale centrally and brown on margins. Iris bronze.

In preservative (after eight years), dark brown background color has become pale brown; blackish line posteriorly bordering the pale occipital band and those blackish lines flanking pale diagonal postrictal band, more conspicuous. Pale occipital band and pale dorsolateral stripes somewhat diffuse, less conspicuous. Whitish dots scattered on dorsum and flanks have faded, almost imperceptible. Iris pale gray.

Cranial osteology. The skull of
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
(
) closely resembles that of
P. barbouri (
Bauer et al . 2018
)
in many aspects. Therefore, we only highlight those character states that differ from
P. barbouri
. Unless otherwise indicated, this osteological description applies to all three specimens examined. A comparative synopsis of osteological character states among
P. quihuai
,
P. barbouri
, and
P. furvus
is presented in Table 2 .

Variation in
type series.
Morphological variation in external phenotypic characters, related to sexual dimorphism, is only evident in the SVL , with females being slightly larger than males ( 31.3â33.6 mm vs . 27.5â30.2 mm ). Regarding morphometry, there is very little variation in the observed body proportions of the
type series. The head is little longer ( HL / SVL = 0.3) in the juvenile MHNLS 21644 ( 0.2 in all the others), whereas it is slender in the subadult MHNLS 22709 ( HL /HW = 1.4 vs . 1.3 in the others). The head is always depressed but the HD/HW ratio is between 0.6â0.7. Finally, the snout is slightly shorter in the adult male MHNLS 22712 ( SL /HL = 0.3 vs . 0.4 in the others). All measurements of the
type series are listed in Appendix 2.

Phenotypic variation is larger in scale counts (Appendix 3) and in the shape and proportions of some head scales; although the concavity of the dorsal-posterior margin of the rostral typically forms an angle of â 90Â°, it is> 90Â° in the specimen MHNLS 22709 . The median postrostral scale can be barely smaller ( MHNLS 21643 , 22709 , and 21644), equal ( MHNLS 22710â11 , 22713 ) or barely larger ( MHNLS 22712 ) than lateral postrostrals. The loreals range between 5â6 and vary in number even between opposite sides of the same individual in four of the seven specimens of the type series. The number of supraciliaries varies between 4 and 5; however, the 2 nd is always the largest. The number of scales of the snout in a transverse line between 1 st and 2 nd supralabials ranges from 19 to 22. The number of both supralabials and infralabials varies from 4 to 5; however, the specimen MHNLS 22710 has six supralabials on the right side. The number of postmentals varies between 4â6, with one or two scales in the middle of the row. The number of lamellae under the fingers and toes varies as follow: FI: 4â5, FII: 7â8, FIII : 8â9, FIV: 7â8, FV: 6â7; TI : 5â6, TII: 7â8, TIII : 8â10, TIV : 8â10, TV : 7â10. The distal subdigital lamellae of the fingers are sometimes divided sagittally, and those of toes are frequently divided. The 1 st subdigital lamella (counted from the tip to the base) is divided in 24 of 70 fingers (34%) and in 58 of 70 toes (83%); the 2 nd lamella is divided in 4 of 70 fingers (6%) and in 23 of 70 toes (33%); the 3 rd lamella is only divided in 5 of 70 toes (7%). The number of scales around midbody is 85â91 and there are 20â22 enlarged ventral scales in a transverse line at midbody. The number of enlarged ventral scales from throat to cloaca is 40â43; and 33â36 from the anterior border of forearms to cloaca, while there are 26â29 ventrals between anterior borders of fore- and hind limbs
.

The color pattern also exhibits some variation in the type series (
). The light occipital band may be ill-defined ( MHNLS 21643 , 22710 , and 22711), evident ( MHNLS 22713 ), or very well defined ( MHNLS 21644 , 22709 , and 22712); regarding color, this light band may be almost immaculate white ( MHNLS 22712 ), dirty white ( MHNLS 21644 , 22709 , 22713 ), light grayish brown ( MHNLS 22710â11 ), or light brown ( MHNLS 21643 ). The light occipital band also varies in form, being medially divided ( MHNLS 22709 ), medially constricted at its anterior margin ( MHNLS 22710 , 22712â13 ), or roughly uniform in its width ( MHNLS 21346 , 22711 ). The blackish-brown transverse line juxtaposed posteriorly to the pale occipital band, is wider and very conspicuous in MHNLS 22712â13 . The pale dorsolateral stripes are absent on neck and dorsum in MHNLS 22711 , and present in the remaining specimens of the type series. There are a series of small, thin, and very-spaced blackish dashes flanking pale dorsolateral stripes from neck to thighs level, in the specimens MHNLS 22709â10 , 22712â13 , which are absent in MHNLS 21643 and 22711. Finally, the juveniles MHNLS 21644 and 22713 are more densely spotted with white on the dorsum and flanks of the body. The ventral surface is quite similar in color pattern in the type series, but immature specimens ( MHNLS 21644 , 22709 , 22713 ) exhibit a thin pale stripe running longitudinally along the posteroventral surface of the thighs.

Distribution, habitat, and natural history.
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
is only known from two localities along the eastern slope of the Cordillera de MÃ©rida in the Venezuelan Andes (
,
). Both localities are in the state of Barinas : El Potrerito â 2.2 km NW from Altamira de CÃ¡ceres ( type locality); and Sendero El Oso, Posada San RamÃ³n, â 6 km N from Altamira de CÃ¡ceres (the northernmost and highest known locality). The known altitudinal range of
P. quihuai
(
1,120 â1,319 m
asl) is occupied by montane semideciduous forests (
), which is mainly characterized by the loss of foliage of most of its tree species during one to three months, in the dry season at the beginning of the year; its canopy is irregular about 20â30 m high, with emergent trees reaching 40 m ; the lower stratum is dominated by Araceae and Cyclanthaceae , and epiphytes are typically scarce in this phytocoenosis ( Ataroff & Sarmiento 2004 ). The natural history of
P. quihuai
remains virtually unknown; the only field notes on the type series indicate that all specimens were collected during nocturnal surveys and all of them were found on the ground, hidden in the leaf litter of the forest and shady coffee plantations. Although the specimens were collected at night (between 21:00â23:00 h), they were not observed actively foraging but were detected by leaf litter removal, which disturbed them, and caused them to move away from their shelters (D. Quihua, pers. comm.). From dissection, we noted that the specimen MHNLS 22711 has a relatively large oviductal egg, still without a calcified shell. The specimen MHNLS 22710 has a small piece of skin shedding inside its stomach. We suspect that is from itself, indicating the occurrence of shed skin eating in this species. Finally, the juvenile MHNLS 21644, the smallest of the series ( 15.4 mm SVL) shows a small and barely perceptible midventral umbilical scar, indicating that it had likely hatched recently.

Etymology. This species is named in honor of JosÃ© Daniel Quihua RamÃ­rez, a young self-taught naturalist and wildlife photographer, particularly passionate about the amphibians and reptiles of Venezuela . Daniel has been an outstanding collaborator of the first author during numerous field surveys and collected the type specimens of the new species.

Remarks. Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed (2000) reported on a specimen of
Pseudogonatodes
(MIZA 15-185 [Museo del Instituto de ZoologÃ­a AgrÃ­cola, Maracay, Venezuela ]) from Las Cuevas, Uribante-Caparo hydroelectric complex, TÃ¡chira state , on the southern part of the eastern slope of the Cordillera de MÃ©rida , Venezuela (sky-blue dot closest to the white cross in
). At that time, the specimen could not be identified to the species level with certainty and the authors considered two possibilities: (i) that it represented an undescribed species, or (ii) a juvenile of
P. manessi
. Since then, specimen MIZA 15-185 had not been reexamined and no new specimens of
Pseudogonatodes
have been obtained from that locality. We reexamined the scale counts reported by Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed (2000) and some additional unpublished scale counts of the same specimen (see Table 1 ), and we preliminary conclude that: 1) The specimen MIZA 15-185 likely correspond to a species of the â3 rd Groupâ as it presents granular juxtaposed dorsal scales and high subdigital scale counts (7 LFIV and 9 LTIV); 2) MIZA 15-185 does not appear to be conspecific with
P. manessi
due to having a lower number of SAM (77 vs . 85â101), VTM (19 vs . 21), VMR-b (34 vs . 37â40), and VMR-c (29 vs . 31â35); in addition, we highlight that
P. manessi
is only known from the Venezuelan Cordillera de la Costa, whereas MIZA 15-185 comes from the southeastern portion of the Cordillera de MÃ©rida (see
); 3) MIZA 15-185 is not conspecific with
P. quihuai
since it has two postnasal scales ( vs . one), three posterior clefts on the mental scale ( vs . mental without clefts), and lower counts of SAM (77 vs . 85â91); and 4) MIZA 15-185 likely corresponds to a still undescribed species, but new data and additional specimens will be required in order to corroborate this hypothesis.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Improving the knowledge on the species diversity and systematics of the dwarf geckos in the genus
Pseudogonatodes
is challenging, not only due to the scarcity of museum specimens and concomitant lack of information on its morphological variation (
;
;
), but also by the paucity in external phenotypic characters useful to readily diagnose and delimit species (
). As in other cases of small terrestrial vertebrates exhibiting low interspecific phenotypic variation and few external diagnostic morphological characters ( e.g. ,
Pristimantis
frogs), quantitative molecular phylogenetic studies will be required in order to test the validity of the current taxonomic hypotheses of species limits and to discover morphologically cryptic species in
Pseudogonatodes
, for which only a few specimens of three species have been sampled in molecular phylogenies ( i.e. ,
P. guianensis
,
P. lunulatus
, and
P. manessi , Gamble 2011b
;
). We also stress the need to increase sampling efforts to reduce the Wallacean shortfall, which also significantly hampers the improvement of our understanding on the species distribution, systematics, and diversity of
Pseudogonatodes
. The discovery of
P. quihuai
, herein described, highlights the still underestimated diversity of this group of Neotropical dwarf geckos and underscores the need for further studies on its taxonomy and systematics.

hypothesized that high toe lamellae counts and an unexpanded third lamella on TIV , which characterizes the third group (currently including
P. furvus
,
P. gasconi
,
P. manessi
,
P. peruvianus
, and
P. quihuai
), may be an adaptation to scansorial foraging, while low counts and an expanded third lamella, as in their first (
P. guianensis
and
P. lunulatus
) and second (
P. barbouri
) groups, is related to terrestrial foraging. They argued that the few observations available at the time on the apparently scansorial habits of
P. furvus
and
P. peruvianus
, and terrestrial habits of
P. barbouri
, supported their hypothesis. Nevertheless, a few additional observations on the natural history of several
Pseudogonatodes species
published in subsequent studies, raised doubts about
hypothesis. For example, the only known specimen of
P. gasconi
has high lamellae counts and unexpanded third lamella (third group) and, as predicted by
, it appears to be scansorial, as it was found on a small tree in a dry varzea forest (
). However,
and
reported on the finding of several specimens of
P. furvus
(a supposedly scansorial species) dwelling on the ground (in leaf litter, under fallen trunks and boulders), while
P. manessi
and
P. quihuai
, both also exhibiting the toe morphology of the third group ( i.e. , scansorial morphology sensu Huey & Dixonâs hypothesis), are typically found in the leaf litter of the forest floor (
; this study) and not on trees or rocky walls as predicted by
. It is clear that further studies in field and laboratory are required to assess appropriately the putative functionality of the toe morphologies observed in
Pseudogonatodes
. Moreover, future molecular phylogenetic studies will shed light on the evolutionary relationships of the group, allowing determination of whether the three phenetic clusters actually represent natural groups and if their toe conditions are synapomorphic.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p:
We thank Daniel Quihua, Daniel CalcaÃ±o, JosÃ© Vieira, Dennys Mora, and the RondÃ³n MartÃ­nez family for logistic support and field assistance during the herpetological surveys in which the type series of the new species was collected. Also, we thank Daniel CalcaÃ±o for sharing his photos of some specimens of the type series in life. To Juliano Romanzini (MCT-PUCRS) for the assistance during the acquisition of high resolution macrophotographs and focus stacking of the holotype . To Adolpho Agustin and the IPR-PUCRS, for the generation of high resolution computed microtomography scans and reconstruction of 3D digital models of the skeletons. To FabrÃ­cio Sarmento (MPEG) for the assistance during the revision of some specimens of
Pseudogonatodes
housed in the herpetology collection of the MPEG. Finally, we thank Teresa Avila-Pires and AndrÃ©s Montes-Correa for kindly sharing with us some unpublished scale counts of the specimen MIZA 15-185. FJMRR acknowledges the financial support from the Institutional Capacitation Program (PCI) of the MPEG â Brazilian Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovations (processes: 317738/2021-6, 300895/2022-4, and 300388/2023-3). ALCP was supported by grants from the Brazilian National Council of Technological and Scientific Development (CNPq) â Process: 302611/2018-5, PROTAX 441462/2020â0).
